NDT: non-diagnostic T abnormalities. These are changes in the T-wave that do not conclusively indicate a specific cardiac condition.
NST: non-specific ST changes. These variations in the ST segment cannot be attributed to a particular cause without further investigation.
DIG: digitalis-effect. ECG changes observed when the patient is on digitalis medication, including ST depression and T-wave inversion.
LNGQT: long QT-interval. Prolongation of the QT interval, which can predispose to arrhythmias, such as Torsades de Pointes.
IMI: inferior myocardial infarction. Heart attack occurring in the inferior wall of the left ventricle, typically detected by changes in leads II, III, and aVF.
ASMI: anteroseptal myocardial infarction. Heart attack located in the anteroseptal region of the heart, usually indicated by changes in leads V1-V4.
LVH: eccentric left ventricular hypertrophy. Enlargement and thickening of the left ventricular wall, often due to pressure overload.
LAFB: left anterior fascicular block. A type of intraventricular conduction delay associated with the blocking of the left anterior fascicle.
ISC: non-specific ischemic. Indicates possible symptoms of ischemia with no specific localization on ECG.
IRBBB: incomplete right bundle branch block. Partial blockage in the electrical impulse conduction of the right bundle branch.
1AVB: 1AVB first degree atrioventricular block. Prolongation of the PR interval with all atrial impulses being conducted to the ventricles.
IVCD: non-specific intraventricular conduction disturbance. A delay in conduction within the ventricles.
ISCAL: ischemic in anterior leads. Signs of ischemia observable in the anterior leads of the ECG.
CRBBB: CRBBB complete right bundle branch block.
CLBBB: Complete left bundle branch block. Full blockage of the left bundle branch, producing a widened QRS complex on ECG.
ILMI: inferolateral myocardial infarction. Heart attack involving the inferior and lateral walls of the left ventricle, identified by changes in leads II, III, aVF, V5, V6.
LAO/LAE: LAO/LAE left atrial overload/enlargement. Increased left atrial pressure or volume, observable as notched P waves in lead II and biphasic P waves in V1.
AMI: anterior myocardial infarction. Heart attack located in the anterior wall of the heart, typically seen in leads V1-V4.
ALMI: anterior lateral myocardial infarction. Myocardial infarction affecting the anterior and lateral walls of the heart, usually seen in leads V1-V6, I and aVL.
ISCIN: ischemic changes in inferior leads. Ischemic signs identifiable in the inferior leads of the ECG (leads II, III, aVF).
HYP: HYP ventricular hypertrophy, enlargement of both the left and right ventricles.
CD: Conduction Disturbance Anterior Fascicular Block. Impairment in the electrical conduction within the anterior fascicle of the ventricles.
INJAS: ischemic in anteroseptal leads. Signs of ischemia present in the anteroseptal leads of the ECG (V1-V3).
LMI: lateral myocardial infarction. Heart attack involving the lateral wall of the left ventricle, often detected by changes in leads V5, V6, I, and aVL.
ISCIL: ischemic in inferolateral leads. Ischemia signs present in both the inferior and lateral leads of the ECG.
ISCI: ischemic in inferior leads. Ischemic changes observable in the inferior ECG leads (leads II, III, aVF).
LPFB: left posterior fascicular block. A type of intraventricular conduction delay involving the left posterior fascicle.
LAFB/LPFB: LAFB/LPFB left anterior/left posterior fascicular block. Conduction disturbances involving both the anterior and posterior fascicles of the left bundle branch..
ISCAS: ischemic in anteroseptal leads. Ischemic patterns observed in the anteroseptal ECG leads (V1-V3).
ISCA: ischemic in anterior leads. Signs of ischemia visible in the anterior ECG leads such as V1-V4.
INJAL: in anterolateral leads. Ischemic injury marked in the anterolateral leads (V3-V6).
ISCLA: in lateral leads. Ischemic indications in the lateral ECG leads (V5, V6, I, aVL).
RVH: right ventricular hypertrophy. Enlargement and thickening of the right ventricular wall, often due to pressure overload.
ANEUR: ST-T changes compatible with ventricular aneurysm. Abnormalities in the ST segment and T wave associated with the presence of a ventricular aneurysm.
RAO/RAE: RAO/RAE right atrial overload/enlargement. Enlargement or excessive loading of the right atrium, often seen as peaked P waves in lead II.
EL: compatible with electrolyte abnormalities. ECG changes suggestive of disturbances in electrolytes like potassium, calcium, or magnesium, electrolytic disturbance or drug (former EDIS).
WPW: Wolf-Parkinson-White syndrome. A preexcitation syndrome characterized by a short PR interval, delta wave, and widened QRS complex.
ILBBB: incomplete left bundle branch block. Partial blockage in the left bundle branch, leading to a less pronounced widening of the QRS complex than seen in complete LBBB.
IPLMI: inferoposterolateral myocardial infarction. Heart attack affecting the inferior, posterior, and lateral walls of the left ventricle, identifiable by specific ECG changes.
ISCAN: ischemic in anterior leads. Ischemic features evident in the anterior leads of the ECG (V1-V4).
IPMI: inferoposterior myocardial infarction. Myocardial infarction involving the inferior and posterior walls of the heart, seen through changes in leads II, III, aVF, V7-V9.
SEHYP: septal hypertrophy. Thickening of the septum, the wall dividing the left and right sides of the heart.
INJIN: subendocardial injury in inferior leads. Damage confined to the inner layer of the heart muscle identified in the inferior leads.
INJLA: subendocardial injury in lateral leads. Injury to the subendocardial layer identified in the lateral leads (V5, V6, I, and aVL).
PMI: posterior myocardial infarction. Myocardial infarction affecting the posterior wall of the heart, often inferred by reciprocal changes in the anterior leads (V1-V3).
3AVB: third degree atrioventricular block. Complete heart block where no atrial impulses are conducted to the ventricles, resulting in independent atrial and ventricular rhythms.
INJIL: in inferolateral leads. Subendocardial injury noted in the inferolateral leads.
2AVB: second degree atrioventricular block. Intermittent failure of atrial impulses to be conducted to the ventricles.
PVC: ventricular premature complex (beat). Early beat originating in the ventricles, appearing as a premature and aberrantly-shaped QRS complex.
STD: ST depression. non-specific ST depression not specific to any particular condition.
VCLVH: voltage criteria for left ventricular hypertrophy. ECG criteria indicating left ventricular hypertrophy based on QRS voltage.
QWAVE: Q waves present. Presence of Q waves, which may indicate previous myocardial infarction.
LOWT: low amplitude T-waves. Reduced amplitude of T waves which can suggest underlying pathology such as ischemia or electrolyte imbalance.
NT: non-specific T-wave changes. T-wave variations that do not conclusively indicate a specific cardiac condition.
LPR: LPR Prolonged PR interval. Elongation of the PR interval which can indicate first-degree heart block.
INVT: INVT inverted T-wave pattern changes. T-waves oriented opposite to the main vector of the QRS complex, often indicative of ischemic or hypertrophic changes.
LVOLT: low QRS voltages. Reduced QRS amplitude in all limb or precordial leads, which can indicate conditions such as pericardial effusion or cardiomyopathy.
TAB: T-waves abnormalities. Any deviation from the normal T-wave morphology which may indicate various cardiac conditions.
PRC(S): PRC(S) premature complex(es). Early beats originating from various cardiac tissues, including atrial, junctional, or ventricular.
SR: Sinus Rhythm. Normal heart rhythm originating from the sinoatrial node.
AFIB: AFIB Atrial Fibrillation. Irregular and often rapid heart rate due to uncoordinated atrial activity.
STACH: sinus tachycardia. Increased heart rate originating from the sinoatrial node, typically defined as over 100 beats per minute.
SARRH: sinus arrhythmia. A natural variation in heart rate occurring during a breathing cycle.
SBRAD: sinus bradycardia. Reduced heart rate originating from the sinoatrial node, typically defined as fewer than 60 beats per minute.
PACE: normal functioning permanent artificial cardiac pacemaker. Proper operation of an implanted pacemaker maintaining heart rhythm.
SVARR: supraventricular arrhythmia. Any abnormal heart rhythm originating above the ventricles, often resulting in rapid heart rate.
BIGU: Bigeminal supraventricular rhythm. A supraventricular rhythm where every normal beat is followed by a premature beat.
AFLT: atrial flutter. Rapid, regular atrial contractions typically resulting in a sawtooth pattern on the ECG.
SVTAC: supraventricular tachycardia. Rapid heart rate originating from above the ventricles.
PSVT: paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia. Episodes of rapid heart rate originating above the ventricles that start and stop abruptly.
TRIGU: trigeminal pattern (unknown origin). A rhythm disturbance where every third beat is of abnormal origin.
2AVB1: second degree atrioventricular block (Type I). Also known as Mobitz I or Wenckebach, characterized by progressive lengthening of the PR interval until a beat is dropped.
2AVB2: second degree atrioventricular block (Type II). Characterized by intermittent non-conducted P waves without progressive prolongation of the PR interval.
ABI: atrial bigeminy. A rhythm in which every other beat is a premature atrial contraction.
ALS: Axis left shift. Leftward deviation of the heart's electrical axis, which may indicate left ventricular hypertrophy or other cardiac conditions.
APB: atrial premature beats. Extra heartbeats originating from the atria, leading to an early heartbeat.
AQW: abnormal Q wave. Pathological Q wave often indicative of myocardial infarction.
ARS: Axis right shift. Rightward deviation of the heart's electrical axis, which may suggest right ventricular hypertrophy or other conditions.
AVB: atrioventricular block. A delay or interruption in the electrical conduction between the atria and ventricles.
CCR: counter-clockwise rotation. The heart's electric axis rotation is less than usual, seen in precordial leads.
CR: clockwise rotation. The heart's electric axis rotation is more than usual, seen in precordial leads.
ERV: Early repolarization of the ventricles. A benign condition often seen in young, healthy individuals characterized by elevation at the J point and concave ST segment.
FQRS: fragmented QRS complex. Presence of additional R waves (R') or notching in the QRS complexes, which can indicate underlying myocardial scar.
IDC: Interior differences conduction. Variations in conduction times within different regions of the heart.
IVB: Intraventricular block. General term for blockages in the ventricles' electrical conduction pathways.
JEB: junctional escape beat. A self-generated beat by the AV node when higher pacemakers fail.
JPT: junctional premature beat. Early beat originating from the AV junction.
LBBB: left bundle branch block. Blockage in the left bundle branch causing a delay in left ventricular depolarization.
LBBBB: left back bundle branch block. Delayed conduction in the posterior fascicle of the left bundle branch.
LFBBB: left front bundle branch block. Delayed conduction in the anterior fascicle of the left bundle branch.
LVQRSAL: lower voltage QRS in all leads. Reduced amplitude of QRS complex observed in all ECG leads.
LVQRSCL: lower voltage QRS in chest lead. Reduced QRS amplitude observed in precordial leads.
LVQRSLL: lower voltage QRS in limb lead. Reduced amplitude of QRS complexes seen in limb leads.
MI: anterior myocardial infarction. Infarction involving the anterior wall of the left ventricle.
MIBW: myocardial infarction in back wall. Infarction involving the posterior wall of the heart.
MIFW: Myocardial infarction in the front wall. Infarction involving the anterior wall of the heart.
MILW: Myocardial infarction in the lower wall. Infarction involving the inferior wall of the heart.
MISW: Myocardial infarction in the side wall. Infarction involving the lateral wall of the heart.
PRIE: PR interval extension. Prolongation of the PR interval indicating delayed conduction through the AV node.
PWC: P wave Change. Any deviation from the normal morphology of the P wave.
QTIE: QT interval extension. Prolongation of the QT interval making the heart susceptible to arrhythmias.
RAH: right atrial hypertrophy. Enlargement and thickening of the right atrial wall.
STDD: ST drop down. Depression of the ST segment typically indicative of ischemia.
STE: STE non-specific ST elevation. ST elevation.
STTC: ST-T Change. Any change in the ST segment and T wave morphology, indicating cardiac abnormalities.
STTU: ST tilt up. Upward sloping of the ST segment often seen in early repolarization syndrome.
TWC: T wave Change. Variations in T wave morphology indicating possible ischemia, electrolyte imbalance, or other conditions.
TWO: T wave opposite. T wave inversion that is opposite to the direction of the QRS complex.
UW: abnormal U waves. Unusual U wave morphology seen in conditions like hypokalemia.
VB: ventricular bigeminy. Rhythm where every normal beat is followed by a premature ventricular contraction.
VEB: ventricular escape beat. Beat generated by the ventricles when higher pacemakers fail.
VFW: ventricular fusion wave. Occurs when a ventricular beat coincides with a normally conducted beat, creating a hybrid QRS complex.
VPB: ventricular premature beat. Premature heartbeat originating in the ventricles.
VPE: ventricular preexcitation. Abnormal early activation of the ventricles often seen in conditions like Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome.
VET: ventricular escape trigeminy. Escape rhythm with every third beat being an escape beat.
WAVN: Wandering in the atrioventricular node. Variation in the pacemaker site within or near the AV node.
SB: Sinus Bradycardia. Slower-than-normal heart rate originating in the sinoatrial node, usually below 60 bpm.
ST: Sinus Tachycardia. Faster-than-normal heart rate originating in the sinoatrial node, usually above 100 bpm.
AF: Atrial Flutter. Rapid atrial rate with a regular rhythm, often creating a sawtooth pattern on ECG.
SA: Sinus Irregularity. Variation in the sinus rhythm due to changes in intrathoracic pressure during breathing.
SVT: Supraventricular Tachycardia. Rapid heart rate originating from the atria or atrioventricular node.
AT: Atrial Tachycardia. Fast heart rate originating from an ectopic focus in the atria.
AVNRT: AV Node Reentrant Tachycardia. A fast heart rate caused by a reentrant circuit around the AV node.
AVRT: atrioventricular Reentrant Tachycardia. Tachycardia caused by a reentrant circuit involving the atria and ventricles.
SAAWR: Sinus Atrium to Atrial Wandering Rhythm. Variation in the pacemaker site between the sinus node and ectopic atrial sites.
